citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
On the day of inspection a free roaming domestic rooster, "Pablo Chickon", was found in the barn and was walking
abnormally (i.e. tips of toes lift during movement and his center of gravity is leaning back). The facility representative
indicated that they noticed approximately 10 days prior that he was laying down more and was slow to start moving when
encouraged to walk. She cleansed his feet and no sores were noted. Although his age is unknown they presume his
symptoms to be age related and the attending veterinarian was not contacted to examine him. Animals displaying
abnormal behavior or postural movements may be in a state of unrelieved pain or distressed if not assessed for diagnosis
and potential treatment by a veterinarian.
The facility must use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries of animals. When
problems with animal health or behavior occur the attending veterinarian must be notified in a timely manner to provide for
adequate assessment and ensure the appropriate diagnosis and treatment.
Correct by September 6, 2024 by obtaining an exam for "Pablo Chickon" by the attending veterinarian and following
veterinary care instructions.

The enclosure for the single housed 2-year-old castrated pig “Wilbur” consists of dirt substrate and a concrete resting pad
where a drinking waterspout and food is provided. “Wilbur” no longer has the option to remain dry and free of mud as the
entirety of the dirt portion of the enclosure has become 100% loose “soupy” mud which is at a depth near the point of his
shoulders and knees when he is standing in it. “Wilbur” can rest on the concrete pad near his water source and food
bucket; however, he must navigate the muddy portion of the enclosure to get to it and the concrete pad is now buried
under approximately 2 inches of mud. The facility representative indicated that he is released into the adjacent pasture at
times, and during the inspection “Wilbur” immediately left the enclosure for the adjacent pasture when the representative
opened the gate.
The ability for animals to stay dry is important for their health and wellbeing including maintenance of healthy skin and
prevention of unrelieved stress and subsequent illnesses. Outdoor housing facilities must be equipped with suitable
methods to rapidly eliminate excess water and allow animals the choice to remain dry.
Correct by September 6, 2024 by ensuring “Wilbur” has housing with an option to remain free of mud and he is not
required to walk through mud to reach his food and water resources.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
